snippet.title: Cricket pay deal opened wounds that now need to heal
snippet.content:
Related Story:
Related Story:
James Sutherland looked tired. No wonder. The late entry of Cricket Australia's (CA) chief executive into the explosive dispute sparked the most intense, focused phase of negotiations, and he was dealing with two parties that had steadily grown more suspicious of each other. Whether he was an integral part of the initial strategy to eliminate the fixed share of forecast revenue, cleave the conditions of the international players from those of their state counterparts, and offer deals to top players to try to divide the group is not clear. , and he was the one who said there was regret on both sides that things became so acrimonious. The Australian Cricketers Association (ACA) chief Alistair Nicholson looked serene. No wonder.
External Link:
Cricket pay deal minimum retainer His language was cautious, his manner respectful, he talked of compromise. But the ACA's own press release listed 18 aims it had, with 18 items ticked off.
The ACA conceded a whack of money for grassroots, and some minor adjustments to their pool of revenue. But otherwise their "compromise" was hard to glean. CA now boasts more flexibility to invest in grassroots and under-funded junior cricket. But it's backed down even further than its revised position in March. The ACA has emerged stronger and emboldened for having stared down their bosses. Was the pain worth it for CA? Sutherland wearily said "history will be the judge". He is right. But the history is done. Now the sport must heal from an episode that revealed ugly backroom brawling behind a great game.
